@raju When you say "Voluntarily", do you also include the financial terms demanded by the publisher? Those things all really matter.
@jayrosen_nyu As I just tweeted to Raju: Saying Outbrain causes damage to the brand is like saying a CMS causes damage because of listicles.
@jayrosen_nyu Jay - as a user, I dont disagree with you. But it's critical to understand the incentives and motives behind what gets served.
@raju It's like saying that a 3rd party CMS is evil because of a listicle published on it.
@raju Has absolutely nothing to do with 1st party vs 3rd party. Has everything to do with the KPI's and incentives within the publisher.
@jason_kint @raju ...but we don't get to make those calls - publishers do. I trust that our partners are smart about how they run their biz.
@jason_kint @raju IMHO - the long term # of RPM's is as important if not more, than the level of each RPM. 80c x 2 is > $1.00 x 1.
@jason_kint @raju ..That is 100% up to the publisher to choose. Outbrain is always a wonderful partner for driving user value above all else
@jason_kint @raju For the long term, the smartest way to use a Content Discovery Engine is by focusing on engagement and user value 1st...
@jason_kint @raju Outbrain can be a fantastic RPM driver for pubs. I dont recommend optimizing for RPM 1st, but understand pubs who need it.
@jason_kint @raju Damages to publisher brands usually caused by their optimizing for RPM's above all else.
@jason_kint @raju 0 brand damage caused by Outbrain. Outbrain is a platform, and can be used in many different ways by smart publishers.
@jason_kint @raju If people are saying Outbrain is wonderful, then you might want consider the option that it is in fact wonderful!...

RT @tkawaja: Is there a blocker for all these articles about ad blockers?
@AlanHogan Agreed. But usage (especially repeat usage) is a fairly good measure of value a person finds in a service. Good night!
@AlanHogan ...that Outbrain provides users with tremendous value.
@AlanHogan Even if some pundits like to whine about it (or some publishers misuse content recommendations), the data overwhelmingly shows...
@AlanHogan When used right, platforms like Outbrain provide a lot of value to the users looking for "what should I read/watch next?"
@AlanHogan Monetization of publisher pages has to be respectful of the user, and provide value, not interruption.
@AlanHogan Not saying we fix ad blocking, but rather that we're a terrific solution for publishers finding that users block ads they hate
@zeldman I'd tweak that: Outbrain could be publishers' solution for ad blockers. Pixels used for user value vs ad interruption.
RT @ischafer: I've said it before and I'll say it again. The future is one with fewer, better ads.  https://t.co/jhnxWkbsA5
@BillyPolcha But as I said: I think the result of ad blocking will be that much more of the content you love will go behind paywalls.
@BillyPolcha @RichBTIG @BenedictEvans @WaltBTIG Yep - it's a very unfortunate loophole. Morally and financially - they're identical.
@RichBTIG @BenedictEvans @WaltBTIG ...I'm sure many consumers will whine and view the old days of free content with ads differently. Alas...
@RichBTIG @BenedictEvans @WaltBTIG Agree. A healthy result of the ad blocking mania is likely to be that a lot more paywalls will be erected
@BillyPolcha @RichBTIG @BenedictEvans @WaltBTIG One costs $'s, the other costs attention to ads. Price set exclusively by the content owner.
@BillyPolcha @RichBTIG @BenedictEvans @WaltBTIG Publisher content with ads is just as copyright protected as a book. 100% the same.
@BillyPolcha @RichBTIG @BenedictEvans @WaltBTIG Oh- don't confuse between the cost you have to pay, and the cost it takes to produce content
@RichBTIG @BenedictEvans @WaltBTIG ...if they choose to set a stupid price (ie- pop-ups, obnoxious ads/trackers, etc) we should go elsewhere
@RichBTIG @BenedictEvans @WaltBTIG Purely morally - yes. The *only* one who gets to set the pricing of their product is the owner/publisher.
@RichBTIG @BenedictEvans @WaltBTIG A browser ad blocker is more akin to walking into a B&N and deciding in advance not to pay for the books.
@RichBTIG @BenedictEvans @WaltBTIG w/DVR the ads were served and got a chance. More akin to buying a newspaper and then cutting the ads out.
@RichBTIG @BenedictEvans @WaltBTIG As an ad blocker moralist, I think those two things are morally different.

RT @jonathanmendez: also getting hung up on lower CPCs is a fool's errand. RPM is they key metric (CPC X CTR) and Google doesn't share that.
@eran_ha :-)
9/9 Sum: CPC can be an important gauge of the demand side health. But as a standalone metric - it's a poor indicator of a business' health.
8/9 If Google's CPC's are declining because it's network is growing so fast, again - that is a long-term good sign for them, not a bad one.
7/9 Last force that might be in play (though not likely at Google's size) - As distribution grows, CPCs can decline (supply/demand).
6/9 Lower CPC also means marketers can run more diverse links on AdWords, with positive ROI. Makes it once again better for Google's users.
5/9 Higher CTR = great for the consumer - better user engagement; Lower CPC = great for advertisers - more affordable marketing channel.
4/9   c) If Google's RPM is OK and its CPC declining = that means that CTR is higher. All those are *good* signs for Google, not bad ones.
3/9   b) It's safe to assume that Google's RPM is healthy - we'd all hear from AdSense publishers if it weren't.
2/9 Google's CPC's falling is likely a *good* sign.    a) what really matters is RPM, not CPC.
1/9 Saying Google is in trouble because of CPC decline is like saying Apple is in trouble because iPhone 5 is priced lower than the iPhone 1

@asaf_birenzvieg Right of first refusal. See all my latest tweets to @cabmania
@Cabmania To sum: If you give an investor a full ROFR on the next round, you basically gave them an option on that investment at their terms
@Cabmania ...and when there is only 1, secure bidder for the round, they get to determine *all* the terms and valuation. Entrprnr has no say
@Cabmania ...meaning that in all likelihood, when someone holds a full ROFR, they are the *only* potential investor for that round.
@Cabmania ...so if they know someone else has a full ROFR and can take the deal, they likely will not want to get involved to begin with...
@Cabmania ...trouble is, an investment takes time & effort. A new investor considering an investment doesn't want to waste time & effort...
@Cabmania ...If you give an investor a ROFR on the next full investment round, that means they have the 1st right to make that investment...
@Cabmania Hmmm - will try in bursts of 140 chars... :-) ROFR = Right of First Refusal
RT @thecajunboy: Mark Zuckerberg should've bought Myspace and gifted it to the Winklevii with the note, "Let's see what you two pricks c ...
@jinner13 OK to give the investor pro-rata participation rights (which is like a ROFR on their % holding). But not on the whole round.
@jinner13 ...I think it shouldn't be a big sticking point for most investors. It absolutely cripples the entrepreneur & the company later
@jinner13 Most legit investors won't ask for it, but I've heard of quite a few that try. IMHO - that should be a non-starter for entrprnrs..

@msuster Unfortunately, saw an entrepreneur today that gave that right to an early stage fund (without understanding what they were doing..)
Tip for entrepreneurs: Do NOT give your early investors a right of first refusal (ROFR) on the entire next round! Can't stress this enough.
